instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.AVREF_SMC: What is AVREF_SMC? AVREF_SMC is a reference voltage provided to the SMC so that its sensors have a reference to work from, this should be 3.3v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> smc io
threads.message:
Have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that had mild water damage. Replaced everything that was affected, Now boots but with high fan speed. Ran ASD and all it says is SMC IO error but doesn't point to anything specific.

Is it best to start out by replacing SMC?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> smc io
threads.message:
NO.
Post entire text messages for ASD errors.
Check if <SIGNAL>SMC_AVREF</SIGNAL> voltage is correct.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> smc io
threads.message:
Not sure how, but board seems to fixed itself when i put it back in machine to run ASD, it now passes and no more high fan spin.

Dont know what <SIGNAL>SMC_AVREF</SIGNAL> is nothing shows up on board view or schematic when I search this.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> smc io
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL> will be highlighted searching on the boardview, I think.

You could have bad contact of some flex probably...
